title: Rose Thomas Bannister // Keenan Lawler // Concetta Abbate
venues: The James Eads How Memorial Cinema
brief_description: The James Eads How Memorial Cinema is pleased to welcome back Rose Thomas Bannister and friends
description:
The James Eads How Memorial Cinema is pleased to welcome back Rose Thomas Bannister and friends! 


Doors at 7pm. Show at 8pm. 

We'll have a few punches and some snacks. Feel free to bring your own beverages and snacks of choice! 


ROSE THOMAS BANNISTER & THE FILTHY UNBELIEVERS

https://rosethomasbannister.bandcamp.com/

New York Music Daily describes Rose Thomas Bannister as “a nimble guitarist, a gripping storyteller, clever lyricist and a strong, dynamic singer with a direct, clear, matter-of-fact voice” and as “one of the most individualistic and interesting songwriters in any style of music.” Raised in Nebraska, where she founded the Clawfoot House venue, Bannister settled in Brooklyn a few years ago after completing a 63 date DIY tour of the whole United States. She is touring this fall with her band, The Filthy Unbelievers, in support of her new EP “Ambition,” a song cycle based on Macbeth. 


R. KEENAN LAWLER

https://soundcloud.com/r-keenan-lawler

is a Louisville, Kentucky based multi-instrumentalist, improviser, composer, and sound artist. For nearly four decades he has been a restless explorer of sound, and maker of music that literally and figuratively falls between the cracks. From a crash course of learning the guitar in the post-punk era to live sampling performances and generative sound installations concerning concepts of spatiality and hypnagogia. Since the late nineties, he is best known for developing a highly idiosyncratic language on the metal bodied resonator guitar, extending its timbral and harmonic range far outside the usual role in bluegrass or blues.


CONCETTA ABBATE

https://www.concettaabbate.com/

'Like many violinists, Concetta Abbate is classically trained, just as likely to be found playing Ravel or Paganini as she is her own music. She finds inspiration in poetry, literature and scientific observation. The point of the “pocket-sized songs” on her loosely thematic new debut album, Falling in Time (streaming at Bandcamp) is that despite how distracted we are by the demands of dayjobs, family and (yuck) technology and social media, we mustn’t cut ourselves off from the world around us because it’s so interesting.... Abbate finds meaning and beauty in the seemingly mundane, translating that tersely and imagistically into a series of brief, often barely two-minute songs that could be called chamber pop or art-rock but really defy categorization.' --Lucid Culture

title: The League: Members Exhibition Opening Reception
brief_description: This three-part exhibition presents a history of the Lexington Art League through the artworks of Early Members (1957-1983), Decades Work by artists involved in LAL for over ten years, who will be showing two works separated by a decade of time, and Current Members’ recent artworks.​ The exhibit will also include a vast amount of historical documents from the Lexington Art League, including publications, photographs, members catalogues, and other interesting memorabilia.
description:
From its inception in 1957, the Lexington Art League has existed as a community-based arts organization to support and celebrate visual artists within and surrounding Lexington, Ky. Members of the organization include artists and patrons near and far, businesses and nonprofit organizations, private and institutional partners, staff and board members. Together, we collaborate and support one another in hopes to enrich our personal and cultural creative growth.


This three-part exhibition presents a history of the Lexington Art League through the artworks of Early Members (1957-1983), Decades Work by artists involved in LAL for over ten years, who will be showing two works separated by a decade of time, and Current Members’ recent artworks.​ The exhibit will also include a vast amount of historical documents from the Lexington Art League, including publications, photographs, members catalogues, and other interesting memorabilia. 


Early Members - Artworks by members active between 1957-1983:

Lillian Boyer, Harold Collins, Dalphna Donnelly, Robert James Foose, Elsie Harris, Marie Hochstrasser, Carol Resser, Neil Sulier, Connie Tucker, John Tuska, and Miriam Woolfolk


Decades Work - Pairing of artworks (one recent and one from appx. ten years ago) by members of ten years or more:

Don Ament, Blake Eames, Liz Foley, Jack Girard, Daniel Graham, David C. Hufford, Margee Koffler, Mary Rezny, Hunter Stamps, Helene Steene, and Clay Wainscott


Current Members - Single artworks by current members who have participated with LAL between 1984 and 2018:

Sara Willa Arthur-Paratley, Martin Beck, Ashley Rainwater Bilbro, Adrienne Dixon, Jamie Donaldson, Susan Goldstein, Melissa Hall, Robert C Henrickson, Tina Hixon, Honora Jacob, Cynthia Kelly, Diane Kline, Robert Lackney, Andrew Light, Jo Mackby, Brian Manke, Brooklynn Messer, Claudia Michler, David Mohallatee, Teresa Montejo, Trish Prewitt, Keith Ross, Benjamin Salley, Barbara Steinrock, and Nick Warner


Opening Reception: September 14th, 6-9pm

title: Opening Night: Insect Virtue
brief_description: Join us for NoLi CDC's September Night Market and the opening reception for Samantha Hensley and Lizz Hamilton's installation, Insect Virtue
description:
Join us for NoLi CDC's September Night Market and the opening reception for Samantha Hensley and Lizz Hamilton's installation, Insect Virtue:


Pursuing all the wonders across the many heavens, a perfect creature wandered down to earth. He admired the humble way things here lived and died, existing only to consume and then to be consumed. Moths spin fluids into silken strands, ants enter into putrid flesh, mosquitos gorge themselves on blood until their little bodies are fit to burst. Seeing this, his mantle radiated with a strange and gentle love for them. These little creatures asked for no awe. Now he inches deeper into the woods, where the soil deepens and the little beings seem to multiply, to his serene enjoyment. 


Now lowly, once divine, he accepts his new form with modest shame. The underbrush hides him from judging sacred eyes, and the insects keep him meager company. From within the forest, sounds emerge, whispering and crying out to him as he passed. Even without thought they know that he is now their guardian; their virtue.

title: Everything Is Terrible's The Great Satan in Lexington
brief_description: Everything Is Terrible!'s T H E G R E A T S A T A N
description:
Everything Is Terrible!’s T H E G R E A T S A T A N


Since the dawn of time, man has searched for answers... and failed. But the fog of existence has finally cleared thanks to the eternal fruits of your favorite found footage collective, Everything Is Terrible! Over the last 10 years, EIT! has reinterpreted our shared memory into 3,000+ daily web videos, collected 15,000 Jerry Maguire VHS tapes, and forever altered the collective consciousness. Now, with their longtime collaborator Lucifer, Everything Is Terrible! has ingested over 2,000 satanic panic, religious kook, and D-horror VHS tapes. They have recontextualized them and created a narrative feature that reminds us all who we are, why we are here, and what we should be doing with our paltry time on this dumb planet. And now they invite you to be an initiate of the psychedelic devotion of EIT! As you take your blood oath, your journey will brim with evangelical ducks, goopy ghouls, and sad white men who believe that Dungeons & Dragons summon actual horned demons. Join your bedazzled Dadgods for an all-new live show, featuring never before seen puppets and costumes, as EIT! presents their newest feature, T H E G R E A T S A T A N. But be warned… If you really want to see your mind, you’ve got to be ready to rip your skull open…


Please bring your offerings of Jerry Maguire VHS tapes to the altar when EIT! comes to your town!


This is a FREE show!

title: Bit Brigade Performs Mega Man II + Castlevania
brief_description: Bit Brigade performs rock covers of full NES game soundtracks as their gamer speedruns the game live on stage
description:
New Cosmic location TBA


Bit Brigade performs rock covers of full NES game soundtracks as their gamer speedruns the game live on stage. 


'When was the last time you attended a live music performance with a genuine element of risk involved? And no, going to a Gwar show with a white t-shirt on doesn't count. When Bit Brigade takes the stage your mind will frantically oscillate between 'Oh! Agh!! Please don't die!!' and 'YES! He's doing it!!' Combining the dread and daring of a live video game speed run with the spot-on technique of a live band covering the musical accompaniment to everything you're seeing on-screen in real time, Bit Brigade will have you swinging between the two mediums. From thrashing about to live renditions of your favorite stage themes, fingers yearning to the sky in a rock 'n roll parody of sea anemones seeming to silently plead, 'Please, feed us more fretboard pyrotechnics!,' to being locked in stock-still rapture as the infallible maestro of the d-pad, Noah McCarthy, takes on the final boss and risks his video game life under the threat of intense peer scorn (or the reward of night-long glory and a credits score). No matter the outcome, Bit Brigade must play on until the deed is done - which it always is - on the first (and last) try. Once Noah’s NES buzzes on, there’s no turning back.' - Metalhead Mike of The Shizz, summer 2011

title: Gook - Free Film Screening
brief_description: Gook - Free Film Screening with Justin Chon & Dr.Donna Lee Kwon
description:
FREE FILM SCREENING: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YNKbFnZvNE

September 12th at 5:30 PM

Gook tells a captivating tale about the tense relationship between Asian Americans and African

Americans during the LA riots; through the unlikely friendship of an Asian American shop owner and an African American girl.

This film aims to uncover the experiences of Asian & African Americans that are often underrepresented in cinema.

The Gatton Student Center Cinema is proud to present this public screening for the city of Lexington and the University of Kentucky students. Followed by a Q&A with director Justin Chon moderated by Dr. DaMaris Hill, this event is free and open to the public if you have any questions don't hesitate to contact us. We hope to see you on September 12th at 5:30 PM.

HIDDEN NARRATIVES: YouTubeMovieclips Indie Gook Trailer #2 (2017) | Movieclips Indie

THE ASIAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCE

The Hidden Narratives series highlights the balancing act that many Asian Americans experience. The act of being true to their Asian heritage while trying to assimilate into the culture that surrounds them.

title: La Notte (presented by the Rosa Goddard Film Festival)
brief_description: Antonioni's film about longing for connection is possibly more relevant now than at the time of its release
description:
SQecial Media is proud to present the first film in this year’s Rosa Goddard International Film Festival!


LA NOTTE (1961, dir. Michelangelo Antonioni) 

We all talk a lot about isolation in today's world. Antonioni's film about longing for connection is possibly more relevant now than at the time of its release. Starring Jeanne Moreau, Marcello Mastroianni, and Antonioni's muse, Monica Vitti, this film takes place over the course of a day and night filled with jazz, smoldering encounters, disillusionment, and modern architecture.


Tickets cost $6 and will automatically enter attendees in a drawing for prizes before the film. Help us spread the word! The next two films in the festival are THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE (September 19) and IDA (September 26). All films will show on Wednesday nights at 7:15pm in the Kentucky Theater. 


Follow SQecial Media or the Rosa Goddard International Film Festival on Facebook for updates:

https://www.facebook.com/sqecialmedia

https://www.facebook.com/rosagoddardfilmfestival

title: Melissa Carter: New Masters, Opening Reception
brief_description: In New Masters, Melissa Carter presents vibrant large-scale paintings that playfully revise the art historical canon and the linked notion of the male-artist-as-genius
description:
Melissa Carter: 

New Masters

curated by: 

Emma Friedman-Buchanan

August 31 - October 13


In New Masters, Melissa Carter presents vibrant large-scale paintings that playfully revise the art historical canon and the linked notion of the male-artist-as-genius. Carter’s figurative and abstract pieces reference the work of famed men, from Henri Rousseau and Henri Matisse, to Mark Rothko and Bill Cosby, employing savvy visual cues to examine the gendered imbalances that underlie their legacies.


When dealing with the figure, Carter takes Rousseau’s and Matisse’s work as sources for her compositions. She stylistically appropriates their use of flat areas of vivid color and pattern, and the collapse of space in their depictions of hired models within carefully staged studios and “exotic” imaginary environments. Yet these settings completely give way to dream-like spaces where women are no longer passive decorative elements. Instead, Carter transforms archetypal images of odalisques, often exotified concubines or sex slaves, into images of powerful women. As chess masters, astronauts, and academic artist-fellows, or as small, rotund genderless figures that freely roam the canvas, all sharply gaze out at the viewer. In Carter’s representations, the one-sided power dynamic between artist and model dissolves through her literal repositioning of women in art.


Playing with popular imagination, her non-figurative works call to mind the grandeur of the highly masculine Abstract Expressionist movement of the mid-1940s and ‘50s. ‘I’m an Oil Man’ prompts associations between the traditional use of oil paint by artists throughout art history, the cultural celebration of male genius-artists such as Mark Rothko and his color field paintings, and the wealth and prestige generated by both oil moguls and famous male artists who continually outsell and overshadow women artists working contemporaneously. In Carter’s ‘Cosby Sweater’ series, smeary, gestural lines and bold colors resemble the knit texture and ‘80s palette of Bill Cosby’s sweaters. The monumental works conflate the Abstract Expressionist qualities of strength, force, and virility with the allegations of sexual abuse committed by Cosby, provoking a sense of cognitive dissonance surrounding the cultural ties between masculinity and greatness.


These images critique traditionally inadequate methods of art historicization and culturally sanctioned misogyny, both of which devalue the identities and contributions of women as artists, models, and human beings. As one of many groups previously left on the margins of critical and cultural conversation, Carter portrays women now in possession of their own image and at the center of their own experiences, revising the social dynamics and representational possibilities of the histories she engages with.

title: Opening Reception for Me, You, and a Few of Our Friends
brief_description: Me, You, and a Few of Our Friends is an international print exhibition featuring works from notable printmakers from the US, Canada, and the UK
description:
Me, You, and a Few of Our Friends is an international print exhibition featuring works from notable printmakers from the US, Canada, and the UK. The intent was to show the interconnected nature of printmaking, and an opportunity to show these ripple effect relationships. Each artist was encouraged to extend the invitation to another artist, and this exhibition is the result; a snapshot of the current printmaking community. 


Participating artists include: Stephanie Dotson, Molly Kaderka, Jake Lee, Brian Hoad, Edith Skeard, Michelle Martin, Joseph Lupo, Elizabeth Elich, Mike Marks, Andrew Kozlowski, Nicole Andreoni, Arron Foster, Jake Lahah, James Ehlers, Amy Sands, Ricardo Ruiz, Melissa Harshman, Sam Orosz, Katie Loesel, Daniel Graham, Dustyn Bork, Rose Briccetti, Joletta Thorburnn, Bobby Rosenstock, Nicole Geary, Joseph Lappie, and Matthew Hansen-Weller.

II, the second annual exhibition featuring recent work of select faculty members from the UK School of Art and Visual Studies. A slight departure from the traditional "faculty show" format, the series occurs annually and represents only a portion of the faculty, with different artists exhibiting each year. This installment includes work in a variety of media including installation, photography, animation, fiber, sculpture, drawing, printmaking, and mixed media.

title: Allie Olson, A Telling: Home
brief_description: Artist and storyteller Allie Olson will enact one-on-one storytelling performances centered around the concept of home. See "more info" for appointment
description:
Allie Olson

A TELLING: HOME

August 23 - 26 by appointment between 12 and 6 PM


Artist and storyteller Allie Olson will enact one-on-one storytelling performances centered around the concept of home. Participants will be invited to write a single word on a small card that relates to a memory they have of home. Olson will then respond to the word with a true story from her life. The performance is an exercise in experimental, improvisational storytelling and intimacy between strangers.


Interested participants are asked to reserve a time slot for their TELLING in advance at the link below, or by reaching out directly to Paul Brown, at paul@institute193.org.  https://193Telling.as.me/

title: The 2018 Woodland Art Fair
brief_description: Featuring over 200 artists, enjoy live music, Kentucky food, beer gardens, and family friendly art engagement activities - all available with free admission
description:
The Lexington Art League and Lexington, KY Parks & Recreation proudly present the 43rd Annual Woodland Art Fair, August 18-19, 2018, on the beautiful Woodland Park grounds (601 East High Street, Lexington, KY 40502).


Featuring over 200 artists, enjoy live music, Kentucky food, beer gardens, and family friendly art engagement activities - all available with free admission! 


Woodland Art Fair has received several national, regional & local honors including being voted a Top 200 Fine Art & Design Show in the nation 2007-2017 by Sunshine Artist Magazine, a Top 20 Event by The Southeast Tourism Society, a Top 10 Festival by The Kentucky Travel Industry Association, and voted as a finalist by readers in the Kentucky Living 2017 Best in Kentucky contest.


Produced in partnership by Lexington Art League and Lexington, KY Parks & Recreation.


Special thanks to this year's Lead Sponsors:

title: Catawampus Universe (NIGHT ONE) at The Burl
Storytelling Public Walks
brief_description: We have an opportunity to reimagine an inclusive public square reflective of contemporary values
description:
In the fall of 2017, two Confederate monuments located at the old Fayette County Courthouse and Cheapside—the site of an African- American slave auction block—were removed. This was a result of both recent and long-standing efforts by a wide range of forward-thinking Lexingtonians.


Subsequently, we have an opportunity to reimagine an inclusive public square reflective of contemporary values. (RE)IMAGINING CHEAPSIDE is a placemaking project intended to build inclusion and healing into the site. Blue Grass Community Foundation is proud to be a partner in this initiative, along with the city of Lexington, Hensley Agency -- State Farm Insurance, and Take Back Cheapside community organizers. Together with internationally recognized author and placemaker Jay Pitter, several placemaking initiatives—intended to build healing and inclusion into the site—are being undertaken. The upcoming Public Storytelling Walks is one of these initiatives. 


This initiative will feature the painful and undertold history related to Cheapside while celebrating wonderful contributions made by African-Americans. Additional walks will celebrate a wide range of Lexingtonians who contribute to making the city a great place on a daily basis:


A farmer unearths his passion for food justice working in a collective urban garden.


A local leader retraces his steps up the fire escape of a formerly segregated movie theatre.


Artists transform the streets into a canvas exploring beauty and interconnectedness.


A family invites us into their living room to share how opening personal space strengthens neighborhood bonds.


All of the walks promise to be engaging and informative; attend one or all of the following: 


African American Walk | Friday August 10 | 7:00pm-8:30pm

Starting Point: Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center — 300 E Third St, Lexington, KY 40508 


African American Walk | Saturday August 11 | 11:00am-12:30pm

Starting Point: Henry Clay Public House — 112 N Upper St, Lexington, KY 40507


Beauty & Sustainability Walk | Saturday August 11 | 2:00pm-3:30pm

Starting Point: The Living Arts & Science Center — 362 Martin Luther King Blvd, Lexington, KY 40508


Belonging Walk | Sunday August 12 | 11:00am-1:30pm

Starting Point: Maria's Kitchen — 805 N Broadway, Lexington, KY 40508 


While you do not need to RSVP for these walks, we encourage you to visit https: www.bgcf.org/events to let us know you’ll be joining us and get a sneak peak at the wonderful Lexingtonians who’ll be sharing their stories and insights.

CRAVE Lexington Food + Music Festival 2018
brief_description: Crave Lexington offers a weekend full of fun for the entire family
description:
6th Annual CRAVE Lexington food + music festival.


Featuring dozens of food vendors from across the Commonwealth, two days of live music, food presentations emceed by Food Network star Jason Smith, bounce houses, art activities, a classic car show, beer, wine and locally crafted cocktails, and much, much more. Crave Lexington offers a weekend full of fun for the entire family.


Admission: $8 (kids 10 & under free)

Parking: Free

Food: Vendors will offer items at $2, $3 & $5 price points

Music: Included with admission.

Bounce houses and other kids’ activities: Included with admission.


What food will be there?

Food is at the epicenter of CRAVE! This year's fest will feature more than 50 vendors, from fine dining establishments to our favorite local holes in the wall. 


What music will be there?

The 2018 music stage will feature a variety of great local and regional acts, from Americana, blues and Motown to punk-inspired bluegrass and psychedelic blues. 


Is CRAVE kid-friendly?

Absolutely! CRAVE Lexington is a family-friendly event with lots of activities for every age group. Kids' programming includes inflatables, face painting, games, hands-on art projects and more. A nursing tent will be available on-site for nursing mothers. 


Who created CRAVE?

Presented by Windstream, CRAVE Lexington is a 2-day food + music festival produced by Smiley Pete Publishing, the independent Lexington-based company behind Chevy Chaser and Southsider Magazines, Business Lexington, Lexington Burger and Pizza Week, Bluegrass BBQ Festival and tadoo.com.


Does CRAVE support a charity?

CRAVE Lexington partners with several charities during the festival, with GreenHouse 17 receiving the largest portion of festival proceeds of all of our non-profit partners. In 2015, 2016 & 2017 CRAVE Lexington contributed over $33,000 to local charities.

title: Talena Sanders: New Movies
brief_description: Talena Sanders returns to Lexington to show two new films
description:
Talena Sanders returns to Lexington to show two new films, 'Between my flesh and the world's fingers' and 'Reasonable Watchfulness.' Like her earlier films, they use the texture of hand-processed motion picture film to reflect on the experience of history, both social and personal. Sanders will attend the screening and do a Q&A after the show.


Between my flesh and the world's fingers (2018), 31.5 minutes.


'Mary MacLane, the Wild Woman of Butte, Montana, published her diaries in 1902 and 1917. As an out queer and proto-feminist at the turn of the century, MacLane became notorious upon the publication of her 1902 diary, I Await the Devil’s Coming. She was whisked away from the industrial hellscape of her copper mining Montana hometown to a life in the public eye as an author, journalist, female film pioneer and always a provocateur - sending up social norms throughout her career, with a special focus on staid notions about women and sexuality.'


'Between my flesh and the world’s fingers is an experimental essay and diary film primarily based on her published diaries and her film work. Though the film is not directly a personal film, the production is founded in part in the act of a woman telling her own story through that of another woman, a trailblazing figure from the past.'


Reasonable Watchfulness (2018) 8 minutes.


'Transitions while longing for other places and people, like a fox on the run.'

title: Love, Peace, and Hair Grease - a Creative Crossover Event
brief_description: The Creative Crossover series, a partnership with Shift Lexington and LexUX, were we highlight local creatives that cross the strict divides of a typical job title.
description:
Creativity reveals itself in many different ways; design, architecture, painting, music, entrepreneurship… to name a few. As a part of the Creative Crossover series, a partnership with Shift Lexington and LexUX, we highlight local creatives that cross the strict divides of a typical job title. This month, we are featuring Jason Glass, co-owner of Cha Cha’s and the Rooster’s Nest, a local salon and barber shop. Jason will share his wisdom and great stories with us inside their shop. Join us for a great conversation, drinks, snacks, and the opportunity to learn more about a Lexington gem.



Jason Bio


Jason Glass has been a colorist and hair stylist for over two decades. Originally from the Muscle Shoals area of Alabama he spent his younger years as a military brat - attending 11 different schools and visiting every continent but the North and South Pole.  Jason, his wife Cha Cha, and their business partner Zac, opened their salon Cha Cha’s in 2008 and The Rooster’s Nest Barber Shop in 2013. Both shops have become a staple for locals and hair industry followers alike.


He is an award winning salon owner, education director,  product developer and stunt double.


What is the Creative Crossover series?


Creative Crossover is a quarterly event created by Shift Lexington and LexUX. Through these events, we highlight creative professionals that blur the lines of your standard job title and description with a variety of events. Any creative person knows that just because your job says you do this one thing, doesn’t mean, on a daily basis, you don’t touch many other areas and fields. Your knowledge is amazing and only experience and grit will get you there. You can look for a Creative Crossover event at least three times a year and you can count on our annual holiday event in December to celebrate the year’s accomplishments and cheer in the new goals.


Past Creative Crossover events include, How Many Hats Do You Wear? a panel discussion, Design + Space, and of course, our Holiday Party.

title: Martha Clippinger: Two Sides/Dos Lados Reception
brief_description: Join us for the reception of Martha Clippinger: Two Sides/Dos Lados. The artist will be on hand to discuss her work
description:
Join us for the reception of Martha Clippinger: Two Sides/Dos Lados on Friday, August 3 from 6 - 8 PM. The artist will be on hand to discuss her work!


Martha Clippinger: Two Sides/Dos Lados

June 29 - August 11


Martha Clippinger (b. Columbus, GA, 1983) makes objects that blur defined borders between painting and sculpture, art and craft, questioning the necessity of such distinctions. Her current work exists in two separate but related modes; modestly-sized brightly painted three-dimensional wall works, and large, bold, patterned ‘tapetes’, or rugs, woven from Clippinger’s gouache drawings. Fittingly, she shares a hometown and draws inspiration from two figures who operate similarly: Eddie Owens Martin and Alma Thomas. Both artists are known for working in saturated color, meticulous pattern, and for creating work that supersedes those same boundaries.


At first glance, Clippinger’s work fits neatly within a lineage of artists working in abstraction within the last century. Her found-object assemblages bear no small resemblance to work by Betty Parsons (1900 -1982), perhaps better known as a legendary gallerist and advocate for abstract expressionists before the movement was well-received critically. The ‘tapetes’ can be seen as related to weavings by artist and textile designer Sophie Taeuber-Arp (1889 - 1943) who also challenged arbitrary divisions between art and craft and championed the use of materials and techniques that had not been used in fine art contexts previously. These artists, of course, are understood as figures situated firmly within the Western art canon and the movements they helped to establish. As is often the case, in the process of their historicization, the non-western aesthetic practices from which they frequently drew inspiration were often forgotten or ignored.


Clippinger’s work, however, is remarkably cognizant of the universal context from which it arises. This is especially true for the tapetes. Abstract graphic adornment of objects, frequently utilitarian ones, is a phenomenon that exists across most of human history and in nearly all cultures; the decorated ‘parfleches’ made by indigenous Americans, abstract tantric paintings from Rajasthan, Australian aboriginal sand painting, and quilts from Gee’s Bend, Alabama, are just a few examples. Clippinger began painting the gouache studies for the tapetes while living in Oaxaca, Mexico. In the weaving village of Teotitlan del Valle, she met a family of rug weavers and approached them about translating her drawings into the tapetes. Since 2014, she has worked with Licha Gonzalez Ruiz and Agustín Contreras Lopez to create the woven works. The process is collaborative, and authorship is shared; rather than asking the couple to alter their wool dyeing process to accurately match her colors, Clippinger uses the gouache drawings as a jumping off point, frequently developing new palettes in response to the colors at hand.


In this body of work especially, the divisions that have been put in place to keep art and craft separate are rendered moot, and the impetus for the establishment of those divisions is laid bare. Frequently the distinction between what constitutes art and craft is determined along lines of gender, race, class, and geography. The work of artists is differentially privileged, legitimized, and valued according to these hierarchies. Clippinger, in recognizing this and making work that actively flattens some of those differences, does important work in undoing the structures that maintain such a system, and does so with levity, humor, and brightness.

title: Off-Spring: New Generations Opening Reception
brief_description: Please join us for the opening reception of OFF-SPRING: New Generations
description:
Please join us for the opening reception of OFF-SPRING: New Generations. Enjoy a cocktail reception at 6pm with remarks from Chief Curator, Alice Gray Stites, followed by a special presentation by featured artist, Stacey Steers.


Rituals—religious and cultural, institutional and domestic—provide the thematic infrastructure for OFF-SPRING: New Generations. These sculptures, paintings, photographs, and videos employ iconographic imagery to explore the development of both personal and group identity, childhood, family, history, and gender politics. At the wedding altar, in the family home, or in the classroom, within the fantasy of childhood play or the familiarity of grown-up habit, these narratives generate a spectrum of meditations on the contemporary construction of self and society.


ABOUT STACEY STEERS

Stacey Steers is known for her process-driven, labor-intensive films composed of thousands of handmade works on paper. Her recent work employs images appropriated from early cinematic sources, from which she constructs original, lyrical narratives. These films investigate the nature of longing, and how desire provokes and mediates experience to create meaning.

brief_description: Closing reception for ALTERED VIEWS. The exhibition explores the 21st century landscape
description:
ALTERED VIEWS: Experiencing The Contemporary Landscape

Closing Fourth Friday

July 27th 6-9pm @ The Loudoun House


FREE to LAL members/students with valid I.D

$5 general public

Special appearances by our partners at Lexington Philharmonic and Kentucky Ballet Theatre

Food and drinks by Sweet LiLu's.


Special thanks to our generous sponsors:

Curated by , ALTERED VIEWS explores the 21st century landscape. No longer romantic, sublime or grandiose, our 'landscape' is viewed primarily through the media of our screens, moving from blissed-out vistas to environmental traumas. Our interest in understanding nature and landscape is often constrained to the poles of beauty or terror, with everyday views overlooked.

title: 193 Sound- Shedding, Rosali, & Josh Mason
brief_description: Institute 193 and WRFL 88.1 FM Radio Free Lexington are pleased to present an ongoing series of FREE experimental music performances, curated and organized by Robert Beatty
description:
Institute 193 and WRFL 88.1 FM Radio Free Lexington are pleased to present an ongoing series of FREE experimental music performances, curated and organized by Robert Beatty

For the July installment we will feature performances from Louisville electronic musician Shedding, Philladelphia singer-songwriter Rosali, and Florida drone improviser Josh Mason, Performances will occur throughout gallery hop, starting at 6PM.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Shedding (Louisville, KY)

“School teacher by day and architect of angular space sounds by night Connor Bell has politely offered his vision of hi-fi (read: it doesn’t sound recorded under water) bedroom pop under the moniker of Shedding for just under a decade. In that time, Shedding has shifted in and out of sonic consciousness, toggling between the type of meditative ambience that earns high marks amongst the Hecker School graduates– such as his 2010 release on Hometapes Tear in the Sun– and a hook-heavy psychedelic amalgam of resonant synths and acoustic noodling. Bell’s latest, Demography, falls clearly within the latter, but with an acute eye toward the mathematical rat race of the Autobahn this go round.” – Kenny Bloggins/TheDecibelTolls

https://shedding.bandcamp.com/


Rosali (Philadelphia, PA)

Philadelphia-based musician Rosali (Long Hots, Wandering Shade) wrote the songs for her second album, Trouble Anyway, seeking empowerment by sharing openly on love, power, aging, suffering, confusion, self-doubt, and anger. Resulting in a full-bodied record that is at once sweeping and intimate. A vulnerable and powerful exploration of emotional narratives, Trouble Anyway showcases her background in diverse musical styles from free improv, garage rock, country, pop, to folk-infused song-craft. Following up her 2016 debut Out of Love (Siltbreeze), named one of the top 100 records of 2016 by Uncut Magazine, Trouble Anyway is a cohesive collection of lush, intimate rock songs, featuring her warm, natural vocals and powerful riffing and rhythm guitar, approaching the sublime when Rosali finds expression beyond lyricism, utilizing her voice as a human instrument. 

https://rosalimusic.com


Josh Mason (Jacksonville, FL)

Josh Mason lives and works in Jacksonville, FL. Balancing improvisation, arrangement and orchestration, his sounds utilize guitars, synthesizers, tape machines and found objects in various processing environments, both analog and digital. While focused on restraint & reservation, he tends to believe that audio works should go on only as long as they need to to convey the idea at hand.

https://j-w-m.bandcamp.com/

title: Charitable Giving and the Arts
brief_description: Join Institute 193 and 21C for an informative evening with attorney Jeffrey Gehring of Dickinson Wright PLLC, and 193 Director Paul Brown for a discussion on how and why you should consider giving to the arts locally
description:
Charitable Giving and the Arts: 

How to Make the Most of Your Giving


21C Museum and Hotel

July 12, 6 - 8 PM


Do you have questions about tax benefits or why the arts need your support now more than ever? Have you ever wondered how to make sure you’re giving strategically to best benefit the organizations you support? Join Institute 193 and 21C for an informative evening with attorney Jeffrey Gehring of Dickinson Wright PLLC, and 193 Director Paul Brown for a discussion on how and why you should consider giving to the arts locally. Also, we’ll have complimentary cocktails on hand featuring spirits from Copper and Kings distillery out of Louisville, as well as a cash bar. Looking forward to seeing you there!


About Jeff Gehring: 


Jeff Gehring is an attorney with Dickinson Wright PLLC. His practice focuses on estate and tax planning and estate and trust administration. Jeff will discuss the potential tax benefits of supporting the arts through charitable giving and offer tips to enhance your charitable giving.


Jeff practices in the areas of estate and wealth transfer planning, including preparing wills, trusts, disability documents and marital agreements; estate and trust administration, including fiduciary representation and tax reporting; and asset protection and closely-held business planning, including family limited partnerships and limited liability companies.


Special thanks to 21C and Copper and Kings for making this event possible

We are thrilled to partner with our friends at the Green Lantern for a tribute to Harry Dean Stanton's love of music!


Jamie James (The Harry Dean Stanton Band, The Kingbees, Steppenwolf, Dennis Quaid and the Sharks) has assembled a new band, Mandeville, and is putting together a set inspired by decades of making music with Harry to kick-start this year's festival. Mandeville, featuring Peach Reasoner and Gina Segall, will share some of Harry's favorite songs in the way that he most loved to perform them: in three part harmony. This will be a VERY special night dedicated to Harry and his love of music by one of the people who knew him best.

title: Music in Transparent Layers
brief_description: MUSIC IN TRANSPARENT LAYERS is an experimental ambient composition by Rob Collier, performed in 10 stages over 10 consecutive days. Each daily performance represents one layer, represented and re-performed audio-visually under every subsequent layer.
description:
Free and open to the public!


MUSIC IN TRANSPARENT LAYERS is an experimental ambient composition by Rob Collier, performed in 10 stages over 10 consecutive days. Each daily performance represents one layer, represented and re-performed audio-visually under every subsequent layer.


ROB COLLIER is a Milwaukee-based composer and performer. His music has been released on auralgamiSOUNDS and Capstone Records in the United States, and Unlabel, WM Recordings, and Greed Recordings in Europe. Collier’s music is meditative and hypnotic, utilizing repetition and simple compositional processes as a means of development. His latest solo release is 13 Stages on auralgamiSOUNDS.


Ben Aguilar (Louisville, Kentucky) is an audio engineer, musician, and educator. His recording and performance work with Rob Collier has appeared on auralgamiSOUNDS, and he has accrued an extensive live performance history as sideman for experimental artists and via the PLAY radio hour and b.u. drone collective, both of which he founded.

title: Crossing Mulholland + Q&A with Tom Thurman and Guests
brief_description: Harry Dean Stanton Fest began in February of 2011 with the premiere of Tom Thurman's incredible Kentucky Muse documentary HARRY DEAN STANTON: CROSSING MULHOLLAND
description:
Opening Night of Harry Dean Stanton Fest!


Harry Dean Stanton Fest began in February of 2011 with the premiere of Tom Thurman's incredible Kentucky Muse documentary HARRY DEAN STANTON: CROSSING MULHOLLAND. We were thrilled to partner with KET on that screening and are excited to bring back the movie that started it all!


As the kick-off to this year's Harry Dean Stanton Fest we will screen CROSSING MULHOLLAND at the Farish Theater on Friday, July 13. The screening will be followed by a Q&A with director Tom Thurman as well as some of the friends and family who are featured in the film: Donnie Fritts, Jim Huggins, and Jamie James!


This is a free event. Doors open at 6 pm and the film will begin at 7.


Since 1992, Tom Thurman has produced and directed over 30 documentaries on art, film, music, sports and literary figures, including Nick Nolte, Warren Oates, Ben Johnson, Harry Crews, Jerry Wexler, Tod Browning, John Ford, Hunter S. Thompson, and Sam Peckinpah. As a producer/writer for Kentucky Educational Television in Lexington, Thurman has directed documentaries for the series Kentucky Muse, a showcase for artists with Kentucky roots. Programs in this series created by Thurman include In the Garden of Music (about musician Harry Pickens), Picture This (about photographer Julius Friedman) and Crossing Mulholland (about actor Harry Dean Stanton).

title: Donnie Fritts & Western Movies at Harry Dean Stanton Fest
brief_description: We are honored that Donnie Fritts and Western Movies are joining us to make sure that it is a true celebration of a life well-lived
description:
For obvious reasons, Harry Dean's birthday was always a tremendous cause for celebration. His friends in Los Angeles gifted him with a big party every year. Now that we are marking the first birthday since his passing, Harry Dean Stanton Fest is picking up the mantle. Henceforward, the festival will take place during Harry Dean's birthday week. This year, his birthday falls on a Saturday and we are honored that Donnie Fritts and Western Movies are joining us to make sure that it is a true celebration of a life well-lived!


One of the architects of the famed Muscle Shoals Sound, legendary songwriter Donnie Fritts is also well-known as Kris Kristofferson's longtime keyboardist and has appeared in a number of films with him including BRING ME THE HEAD OF ALFREDO GARCIA and PAT GARRETT & BILLY THE KID (also starring Harry Dean). A native of Florence, Alabama, Fritts played drums with local acts like the Satellites and Hollis Dixon as a teen. By the late 1950s he was writing and performing with the likes of Arthur Alexander, Dan Penn, and Spooner Oldham, all of them joining forces to forge the unique fusion of Southern soul, pop, country, and R&B immediately recognizable as the Muscle Shoals Sound. Fritts is a songwriter's songwriter and his music has been recorded by Willie Nelson, Percy Sledge, Dusty Springfield, Ray Charles, Dolly Parton, and the Rolling Stones (just to name a few).


Based in Lexington, Kentucky, Western Movies is the song-writing/recording project of Chris Sullivan. Western Movies is a travelogue of organic musical styles ranging from surf pop and old school lounge to exotica twang, instrumental film music, and cinematic acoustic folk blues. 


Doors open at 8 pm and the show will begin at 9. Before the show, Local Trivia Action will host Harry Dean Stanton Trivia at The Burl Arcadebeginning at 7 pm.


21+

title: Opening Night: Area/Matter by Adrienne Dixon
brief_description: Join us for July's Night Market and the opening of Area/Matter, a solo exhibition of work by Lexington artist Adrienne Dixon
description:
Join us for July's Night Market and the opening of Area/Matter, a solo exhibition of work by Lexington artist Adrienne Dixon:


Area/Matter Is an exhibition about the spaces and materials we encounter by means of color, texture, and geometry.


Space or area and materials or matter lend themselves to one another. There have to be materials or objects to build or create space, at the same rate there has to be space for matter to fill.


We are all effected by the spaces we occupy and encounter every day; we associate memories and emotions with these areas we experience. Much like the spaces we encounter the materials we come across also have a similar association. Often times when we see a material it triggers a memory for us or can generate a new memory based upon the aesthetics of that particular material.


--


Adrienne Dixon is a mixed-media artist from Avenue, Maryland, living and working in Lexington, Kentucky. She received her Bachelor of Fine Arts in painting from the Savannah College of Art and Design in 2011, and her work has been shown across the Eastern United States, as well as being in many private collections across the nation. 


Currently, she is working as a studio artist, serves as Secretary of the Bluegrass Printmakers Cooperative, teaches fine art classes to all age groups, and volunteers at the Lexington Art League.


--


Free and open to the public.


Viewers are invited and encouraged to draw or write on the sculpture that is a part of this exhibition.

description:
Excessive Realness, a dance intensive geared toward LGTBQIA+ dancers and performing artists, has opened registration and is welcoming participants!


The intensive takes place at the Pam Miller Downtown Arts Complex in Lexington, KY, Tuesday June 26th to Friday June 29th, 2018. Classes begin at 10am on Tuesday and the intensive ends with a performance, called The SPILL, on Friday evening. The performance is free and open to the public. 


Register NOW!


The intensive costs $150 total, plus a registration fee. This includes 12 classes, 3 roundtable discussions with artists, and priority seating for the performance. We have financial scholarships available. If you are in need of a financial scholarship, please contact us.


The Guest Artists, who will both teach and perform at the intensive, are:


Ya-Ya Fairley, 

teaching 'Disruptive Bodies: Performance Lab in Bodily Release and Resistance'


Kristi Faulkner (Kristi Faulkner Dance), 

teaching 'Falling & Rolling'


Ally Garcia, 

teaching 'Hip Hop' 


Anna Maynard, 

teaching 'Improvisation: An act of 'homing'


Donald C. Shorter Jr.,

teaching 'Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Masterclass'


We are very excited for all of the Guest Artists! 


This intensive is the first of its kind in the US and we hope that you will consider being apart of this amazing opportunity.


Saturday

Any questions or concerns can be answered by the Co-Directors Allison Blakeney (Allison.Blakeney@gmail.com) and Anthony Alterio (Anthony.m.alterio@gmail.com), or send them a message on the Excessive Realness Facebook Page.

title: The SPILL
brief_description: The SPILL is a queer dance performance where the teachers/guest artists of Excessive Realness will showcase their current work
description:
The SPILL is a queer dance performance where the teachers/guest artists of Excessive Realness will showcase their current work! The performers take the audience on a journey through internalized shame of gender non-conformity, a consideration of black trans joy at the intersections of vulnerability, desire, and rage, the exploration of aging and coming out, and considerations of audience/performer boundaries. Each bold performer takes refuge in vulnerability while also challenging the audience to reflect on the boundaries of this vulnerability, and its lines of safety, love, and acceptability. 


There will be a performance followed by a talk-back with the artists. FREE AND OPEN TO THE PUBLIC, JUST SHOW UP!

title: Closing Party: Frank by Whitefox
brief_description: Come by and see the June exhibition, Frank, on closing night and enjoy electro house music DJ'ed by Joe Clark and David Austin
description:
Come by and see our June exhibition, Frank, on closing night and enjoy electro house music DJ'ed by Joe Clark and David Austin.


Frank documents and reexamines the symbol of the phallus in the contemporary South. By flipping the traditionally heteronormative male gaze of the female nude, Whitefox queers Southern male culture and its violent subtext of threatening dominance, penetration, power, identity, fear of self, and fear of others. Both anonymous and incredibly intimate, the models are often strangers to the artist. The amount of trust, vulnerability, but also joy and pleasure of exposing one’s own body is revealed and playfully voyeuristic. The back rooms and bathrooms of bars and restaurants are the settings for these images, providing the intense and messy tone of the working class service industry, of which the artist himself is an institutional part. These portraits reimagine the phallus as a symbol of protest against toxic masculinity and the religious and societal norms that restrict our definition of male identity. 


Whitefox is a Lexington based multimedia artist and bartender. He studied photography at Andrews University and has shown his work throughout the American South.


--


Warning: This exhibition contains graphic nudity and may not be appropriate for children.


BYOB 21+. Free and open to the public.

title: Mind Over Madness
brief_description: Join creatives from around the Mid East, including Louisville, Lexington, Indianapolis, Cincinnati, and Nashville. Be with us, as we try and find, our Mind Over Madness.
description:
*This Event is Completely Free, and Available to All Ages // 21+ to drink. (Drinks will NOT be sold on premise). See below for a list of all the creatives.*



In a world ran by technology, social media, government propaganda, and the ever looming threats of war, it's difficult to find peace in the chaos. The fear of isolation, desolation, and degradation created what many are led to believe as a modern dystopia. Surprisingly enough, many believed much of these modern travesty wouldn't even exist, let alone set us in turmoil, merely 18 years ago.


On the brink of the millennia, Y2K, the decadence of the growing society either celebrated its sudden collapse, or reveled at its apocalyptic forthcoming. A dire time it was, to find any salvation we could.


Through the reality of fear, pain instilled within the culture. People rioted, fought in outrage, and expedited their own predicted end. And yet. Through all of the pain, many found salvation through the pursuit of pleasure. Side tracking their angst and fear, with embracing the luxuries and celebrations of the times.


Mind Over Madness is the bridge that connects these two seemingly distinct worlds. Content raging from Visual Art, Fashion, Dance, and Live Music, all encompassing the ideals of pain v. pleasure and how we as people either succumb or rebel to the inner makings of our very existence.


Join creatives from around the Mid East, including Louisville, Lexington, Indianapolis, Cincinnati, and Nashville. All coming together to deliver an experience only rivaled by the human phenomenon. Be with us, as we try and find, our Mind Over Madness.


Brought to you by:

-The Parachute Factory

-The Liberty House Series


Sounds Enhanced by:

-$weetboy (Jon$ey)


Lights and Audio by:

-Chris Wheeler


Creative Director:

-Jake Mannino

-Brandon Wiitala


Visual art:

-DeeDot King

-Preston Harris

-Homegrown Collectives

-Never Have a Bad Day

-PJ

-Forrest Schmitt

-Jordan Lanham

-Cali


Dance:

-Javier Perez


Music:

-Nostalgic 1996 Collective

-Mike Bandanna

-Suicide Rascal


Charitable Cause:


To help combat the impending future we all face, we will be collecting donations to give some of the proceeds to the local Cincinnati charity, Mill Creek Alliance. They are working to restore Mill Creek (which is actually a river), which over 20 years ago was listed as one of the top five most polluted rivers in the country, after years and years of companies in Cincinnati dumping waste straight into it. Now, through the Mill Creek Alliance, Mill Creek is no longer on that list, as almost every single major polluting site has been shut down, and now native species of animals are starting to return to the creek. Mill Creek became a physical representation of the dystopian world we have created, but still symbolizes a hope for change. Help us support our model of peace in this decaying world.


You can find more about the organization through the groundwork’s website: http://groundworkcincinnati.org


Also follow them at:

title: Introduction to The Welcome Card
brief_description: The event is a The Welcome Card collaboration with the faculty and students of the UK School of Art and Visual Studies (SAVS). Presented by Shift.
description:
A Look Into a Systemic Digital Solution to Immigration Processes. 

-----

The Welcome Card is a Stockholm-based initiative founded in May 2016 at the peak of the European refugee crisis, when Sweden received 162877 asylum applications in one year. It calls for a systemic solution to the current asylum seeking and immigration crises unfolding around the world, proposing a digital platform that allows asylum seekers to individually login and navigate their own case status via mobile and desktop, and to access early-inclusion activities and existing public services, such as public transportation, language courses, cultural and networking events. 


For the past month, Veronica Polinedrio has been working with UK School of Art and Visual Studies faculty and students to develop an early stage prototype of the platform.


This event is a The Welcome Card collaboration with the faculty and students of the UK School of Art and Visual Studies (SAVS). Presented by Shift. The discussion will focus on the Welcome Card and how SAVS contributed to the design and workflow of the solution. We will talk through the current process and future steps for the project. 

-----

To continue the conversation, we will meet in the Lockbox Lounge after the event.

description: Karl Blau – Skagit Valley born and bound multi-instrumentalist birthed many varieties of records as well as a quantity around 45 titles by 2017. Anticipating another Bella Union, (London label) release in November entitled 'Out Her Space' which features a funk and jazz rock variety, 2016's first BU release 'Introducing Karl Blau' garnered Blau a title for crooner in the country/soul sound. Karl Blau toured Europe, specifically the UK, extensively in 2016 and 17 and by contrast you could see him at Anacortes Farmer's Market playing for folks there in his home town. His band members have included an incredible rotating cast of NW musicians mostly of the band LAKE for his country/soul set and featured Jon Hyde on pedal steel; as a soloist, live Blau integrates the recording process with live looping and effects, usually with guitar accompaniment.

Opening Night: Frank by Whitefox
brief_description: Frank documents and reexamines the symbol of the phallus in the contemporary South. By flipping the traditionally heteronormative male gaze of the female nude, Whitefox queers Southern male culture and its violent subtext
description:
Join us for the opening night of Frank by Whitefox.


Frank documents and reexamines the symbol of the phallus in the contemporary South. By flipping the traditionally heteronormative male gaze of the female nude, Whitefox queers Southern male culture and its violent subtext of threatening dominance, penetration, power, identity, fear of self, and fear of others. Both anonymous and incredibly intimate, the models are often strangers to the artist. The amount of trust, vulnerability, but also joy and pleasure of exposing one’s own body is revealed and playfully voyeuristic. The back rooms and bathrooms of bars and restaurants are the settings for these images, providing the intense and messy tone of the working class service industry, of which the artist himself is an institutional part. These portraits reimagine the phallus as a symbol of protest against toxic masculinity and the religious and societal norms that restrict our definition of male identity. 


Whitefox is a Lexington based multimedia artist and bartender. He studied photography at Andrews University and has shown his work throughout the American South.


--


Warning: This exhibition contains graphic nudity and may not be appropriate for children.


Free and open to the public. 21+ BYOB

title: Altered Views
brief_description: ALTERED VIEWS explores the 21st century landscape. No longer romantic, sublime or grandiose, our 'landscape' is viewed primarily through the media of our screens, moving from blissed-out vistas to environmental traumas
description:
ALTERED VIEWS: Experiencing The Contemporary Landscape

Opening Fourth Friday

May 25th 6-9pm @ The Loudoun House


FREE to LAL members/students with valid I.D

$5 general public

Food and drinks by Sweet LiLu's with music by Volare String Quartet.


Special thanks to our generous sponsors:

Mediocre Creative

LAVA Systems/Security

LexArts

Walter Gross III



Curated by Alice Pixley Young, ALTERED VIEWS explores the 21st century landscape. No longer romantic, sublime or grandiose, our 'landscape' is viewed primarily through the media of our screens, moving from blissed-out vistas to environmental traumas. Our interest in understanding nature and landscape is often constrained to the poles of beauty or terror, with everyday views overlooked. 


Participating Artists: Katlyn Brumfield, Charles Ellis, Steven Foutch, Jr., Eric Kniss, Magnolia Laurie, Meredith Leich, Logan Marconi, Emily Hanako Momohara, Emily Moores, Rachel Rampleman, Erica Stoller, Tanya Synar, Travis Townsend, Lisa Young, C. Jacqueline Wood,Terry Berlier & Llewelynn Fletcher, Maidens of the Cosmic Body Runnning: Denise Burge, Lisa Siders, Jenny Ustick


Exhibition dates 5/25-7/29

Gallery hours are free and open the public

(Tues-Thurs: 10a-4p, Fri: 10a-8p, Sat-Sun: 1-4p)

title: Closing reception 'Sharing Time and Space'
brief_description: The contrasting styles of primitive sculptures, drawings and paintings by Paolo Dal Prá are displayed along with the detail oriented secular mandalas by Carleton Wing.
description:
Closing Reception and Gallery Hop

The contrasting styles of primitive sculptures, drawings and paintings by Paolo Dal Prá are displayed along with the detail oriented secular mandalas by Carleton Wing. Inspired by the art of Tuscany, Paolo Dal Prá (1943-2017) creates his sculpture in wood, paper and clay. Thriving on detail, Carleton Wing creates his secular mandalas from objects he finds in his studio, manipulating them digitally until there is no beginning or end. For a brief time, these two old friends will share time and space in the gallery.

title: ShareTheLex Mural Challenge Insta-Meetup
brief_description: In celebration of National Tourism Week, we are inviting you to our#ShareTheLex Mural Challenge Insta-Meetup
description:
CALLING ALL PHOTOGRAPHERS AND INSTAGRAMMERS.


In celebration of National Tourism Week, we are inviting you to our #ShareTheLex Mural Challenge Insta-Meetup!


If you haven't noticed, Lexington is becoming a live street art gallery and we want to show it off to the world! Beautiful, inspiring and provocative street murals are popping up everywhere and what better way to show our appreciation for them than to gather with locals who love Lexington just as much as we do? Join us to celebrate National Tourism Week and to help spread the Lexington love on social media using #ShareTheLex. 


We will be meeting at the Lexington Visitors Center, 401 West Main Street, located between Tony's and Pies and Pints. 


The route will be a 60-minute walk around downtown to visit a few of Lexington's street murals. We will begin at the visitors center, then we will head up Broadway Street, on to Short Street and end with a small celebration at Oscar Diggs! 


You'll be able to meet local photographers and instagrammers who love Lexington just as much as you do.


Bring your family, bring your friends and don't forget your camera - we hope to see you there!


----------------------------------------------------------------


When you arrive at the Lexington Visitors Center for check-in Nora Brunner will be your contact.


Please email nbrunner@visitlex.com with any questions or if you are having trouble finding the visitors center the day of the walk. 



10:30a | Meet & Greet + check-in


11a | Instagram/Photowalk starts


12p | Organize for a group photo at the last mural and head to Oscar Diggs


Hashtags to use: #ShareTheLex #InstaMeetLex

title: St. EOM: Pasaquoyanism
brief_description: St. EOM pulled from myriad sources that span time, geography, and culture to build the system of beliefs on which his art and life’s work was founded
description:
'PASAQUOYANISM IS THE NEXT THING, MAN, IT IS DEFINITELY WAITING IN THE WINGS!!! It means the end of all these Buddhists and Muslims and Christians and all this other shit, man. I just hope I live long enough to establish it.'


Eddie Owens Martin (1908 - 1986), better known as St. EOM, founded his own religion, Pasaquoyanism, in response to visions he had that started in his early twenties. In them, he was visited by giant men with long beards parted down the middle and hair that stood straight up from their heads. They instructed him to build Pasaquan, an expansive compound in his hometown of Buena Vista, Georgia, on which he built pagodas, temples, shrines, and dance floors made of cement and sand lavishly decorated with bright patterns and bas-relief, vividly painted representations of the beings that would continue to visit him over the course of his life. 


Martin left Georgia at the age of 14, hitching his way North to New York City. He spent the next three decades there, working as a hustler and tea room clairvoyant. For several years, he ran a gambling den and sold Georgia-style fried chicken and hand-rolled marijuana cigarettes out of his apartment in Harlem. In 1942, the operation was busted, and he was sent to the Federal Narcotics Prison Hospital (known colloquially as the Narco Farm) in Lexington, Kentucky, where he and most of the inmates, by most accounts, enjoyed themselves thoroughly. The friendships made while he was in the area would later lead a number of Lexingtonians, among them Robert Morgan and Guy Mendes, to make pilgrimages to Pasaquan in the 70s and 80s. 


Martin returned to New York in 1943, and, when not reading tea leaves or waiting tables at the Howdy Club, a popular gay nightlife spot at the time, painted constantly. Frequently too poor to afford paper or canvas, Martin often made use of scrap wood and metal as a painting surface. The work from this period mirrors the style and subject that would later come to define the murals and totems of Pasaquan. From an interview with Tom Patterson in 1983: 


“I was paintin’ like mad in those days,” he recalled. “I’d go to work in the tea room from 3:00 to 10:00, then I’d get back home and light up a joint or two and go to work on the paintin’ I had on the wall. I was paintin’ scenes of ancient Mayan temples and some of the other ancient civilizations, and some pictures of the heads with the upswept hair. All kinda things—beautiful paintin’s. I tried to get some of my art in the galleries in New York, but I just couldn’t ever get through. It was just … Well, it just wasn’t like the average art. It was too bizarre for ’em.”


In the mid-1950’s, another vision instructed Martin to go home to rural Georgia and begin work on Pasaquan, which he would build and maintain throughout the rest of his life. St. EOM pulled from myriad sources that span time, geography, and culture to build the system of beliefs on which his art and life’s work was founded. Pasaquoyanism, although it is a cult of one, continues to draw interest by examining thoroughly the roots and intricacies of so many systems of situating oneself within the spiritual world, and in that pursuit finds elements that are genuine and common to all of them.


This collection is made available by the courtesy of Columbus State University, Columbus State University Foundation, Inc., Pasaquan in Buena Vista, Georgia, and through a gift by the Kohler Foundation, Inc. Special thanks to the Atlanta Contemporary, Daniel Fuller, Guy Mendes, and The Faulkner Morgan Archive. 


For all Press Inquiries, contact Paul Brown at paul@institute193.org

title: KWAR Fundraiser: Frank X Walker, Mary Ann Taylor-Hall & FuzzCuzz
brief_description: This evening is a benefit for Kentucky Writers & Artists for Reforestation, the brainchild of Kentucky writer Erik Reece
description:
A fundraiser for Kentucky Writers and Artists for Reforestation! 

Readings start at 8PM 

$5

Poetry by: Frank X Walker & Mary Ann Taylor-Hall

Music by: FuzzCuzz


This evening is a benefit for Kentucky Writers & Artists for Reforestation, the brainchild of Kentucky writer Erik Reece, which is a new nonprofit for Kentucky artists and writers to make our own political statement by planting thousands of native hardwood trees on old strip mine sites throughout Appalachia, with generous help from Green Forests Work, a forestry nonprofit dedicated to reforesting Appalachia's denuded hills. All of the evening's proceeds will grow the coffers for future reforestation events and we welcome anyone interest to join us in these plantings.


Learn more at https://www.kentuckywritersandartistsforreforestation.site/

The sold-out November 2017 show featured 35 Central Kentucky artists coming together in 13 acts to bring their considerable talent and respect to Cohen’s incomparable catalog. Two new performers will join the original artists in the reprise: 17-year old multi-instrumentalist and soulful vocalist, Daisy Helmuth, and Paul K, a staple of the Lexington blues and folk scene in the 90’s.


Original artists include One Lane Bridge, Colin Fleming, Paper Moon Trio, Quantum Mechanics, Four Leonards (and a Fifth), The Sherry Sebastian Trio, The Partisans, Doc Feldman with Art Shechet, The Joanna James Trio, Nevi’im, and Lauren Hill, Lorne Dechtenberg and Diane Arnson Svarlien.


“A startling Leonard Cohen Tribute…If there was a single concert event that underscored a sense of community this year it was the November summit honoring the songs of Leonard Cohen. There were wonderfully unspoiled and inventive interpretations of Cohen’s often prophetically poetic works that culminated with the artists and the audience singing ‘Hallelujah’ together…A rich and stylistically far-reaching overview.” -- Walter Tunis / Lexington Herald Leader


“For six decades, Leonard Cohen revealed his soul to the world through poetry and song—his deep time and timeless humanity touching our very core. Simply brilliant. His music and words will resonate forever.” –Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, 2008

Co-produced by the online cultural affairs publication UnderMain and Purple Carrots Productions.


Get your tickets early. The first show sold out quickly!

Unstitched is a Fiber Art Show curated by Jessica Simpson. The show is a non-traditional curation of work aimed to create an environment where you can hang out with the work and socialize with it. It is a group show with no rules; just art and fiber. 


What the heck is fiber art?! It could be all things soft, furry, found, woven, or stitched...creepy, reminiscent or just plain cool... Come by and find out!


Featured artists will be UK SAVS artists:

Liz Moore, Cooper Gibson, Alex Lewis, Kaley Kemplin, Nicolette Lim, Samantha Hensley, A. E. Stone, Jessica Simpson, Marguerite Kellam, and Ali Deane. 


As a soon to be graduate, with a desired future in curation, my mission is to help young working artists strengthen their career in showing work. So this show is a graduating project to help my friends and colleagues get to show their art and celebrate their hard work as the end of the year, and graduation approaches. Come support and have fun!

title: OJS Presents: Chris Potter
brief_description: We're very excited to present one of the biggest living names in jazz, Chris Potter, live at the Lyric Theater
description:
"Easily the most compelling saxophonist of his generation."

- Detroit Free Press


We're very excited to present one of the biggest living names in jazz, Chris Potter, live at the Lyric Theater.


A world-class soloist, accomplished composer, and formidable bandleader, Grammy Award winning saxophonist Chris Potter has emerged as a leading light of his generation. Potter’s music showcases limitless creativity and a vibrant sense of swing, prompting critics, musicians, and fans alike to cite him as the one of the finest saxophonists today.


The New Yorker calls Potter, “A tenorist who can remind you of Joe Henderson at his craftiest, he employs his considerable technique in the service of music rather than spectacle.”


Throughout his career, Potter has performed and recorded with artists as diverse as Steely Dan and Herbie Hancock, and has toured the world over with the Dave Holland Quintet, the Overtone Quartet, AZIZA, and the jazz-funk group, Chris Potter’s Underground.


The Dreamer is the Dream, by the Chris Potter Quartet, is the current chapter in Potter’s storied career.

title: 2018 SOfAH Symposium
venues: Bolivar Art Gallery - UK School of Art
brief_description: The UK Student Organization for Art History (SOfAH) presents its first interdisciplinary symposium, on the relationships between aesthetics and politics
description:
The UK Student Organization for Art History (SOfAH) presents its first interdisciplinary symposium, on the relationships between aesthetics and politics. 


In today’s sociopolitical climate — where protesters regularly take to the streets with visually striking signs that claim their right to representation and fight discrimination on the basis of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, religion, and nationality — the political potential of aesthetics demands attention. Furthermore, as powerful politicians deploy images on social media with the aim of manipulating their publics, the role of aesthetics in politics has become a vital issue to consider.

This symposium aims to address the question: What role does aesthetics, with its emphasis on nature, representation, and subjectivity, play in today’s political climate?


PRESENTERS:

Jonathan Wright, 'The Abstraction of ‘the Political’ in Aesthetic Discourse'

Kristen Hankins, 'How did the feminist movements of the 1960s-70s impact women’s advancement in the workplace?'

S.F. Means, 'The Black Power Aesthetic: Tracing Political Symbols from California to São Paulo'

Charlsa Hensley, 'Counter/Collective Memory on Monument Avenue'

Gabe Tomlin, 'The Darker Planets'


Light refreshments will be provided!

title: The Watermelon Woman
brief_description: Cheryl Dunye's debut feature is as controversial as it is sexy and funny
description:
There are no trailers, just clips online

Cheryl Dunye's debut feature is as controversial as it is sexy and funny. Cheryl is a twenty-something black lesbian working as a clerk in a video store while struggling to make a documentary about Fae Richards, an obscure black actress from the 1930's. Cheryl is surprised to discover that Richards (known popularly as 'the Watermelon Woman') had a white lesbian lover. At the same time, Cheryl falls in love with a very cute white customer at the video store (Guinevere Turner from GO FISH). Such are the complexities of race and sex in this startlingly fresh debut, which has been attacked by conservative Congressmen for having been funded by the NEA and lavishingly praised in the editorial pages for being charming and courageous.

title: R.C. May Photography Lecture: Karen Irvine
brief_description: FREE lecture by the Chief Curator and Deputy Director of the Museum of Contemporary Photography at Columbia College Chicago
description:
FREE lecture by the Chief Curator and Deputy Director of the Museum of Contemporary Photography at Columbia College Chicago. Karen Irvine helps to lead one of the most vibrant centers for photography in the Midwest, while also working on projects internationally. She will speak on her approach to uncovering and supporting the work of emerging and mid-career photographers through a rigorous program of exhibitions, publications, special projects, and acquisitions.


Irvine has organized more than fifty exhibitions of contemporary photography at MoCP and other venues, among them the Lishui International Photography Festival, China; Daegu Photography Biennale, South Korea; and the New York Photo Festival. Her exhibitions include Petcoke: Tracing Dirty Energy; North Korean Perspectives; and Grace of Intention: Photography, Architecture, and the Monument. She is also a frequent writer on photography, contributing to numerous journals and books.

title: Urban Forests: A Natural History of Trees and People in the American Cityscape
brief_description: Author and historian, Jill Jonnes, gives a talk on her book 'Urban Forests: A Natural History of Trees and People in the American Cityscape.'
description:
On Wednesday, April 11th, from 6:00pm-8:30pm, the Urban Forest Initiative will be hosting an event featuring a talk given by author and historian Jill Jonnes in the William T. Young Library Auditorium on UK's campus. The talk, which starts at 7:00pm, will focus on themes from Jonnes' book Urban Forests: A Natural History of Trees and People in the American Cityscape. Urban Forests provides a unique perspective on urban environments and captures the history of cities and people’s connection to nature through the lens of urban trees and their champions.


There will be a social hour and book signing preceding the talk starting at 6:00pm. There will be refreshments from UK Catering and exhibitors from various environmental organizations in Lexington. This is a great opportunity to network with local organizations and to meet with other community members interested in environmental work.


FREE parking is available is the Rose Street garage off of Hilltop Avenue. Ticketing will be prohibited in this area starting at 5:30p.


Jonnes will also be doing a reading and book signing at Brier Books on Tuesday, April 10th, from 5:30pm - 7:00pm.

title: A Musical Journey Through Russia
brief_description: The Russian folk trio Zolotoj Plyos plays music from across Russia in this lively performance of music lovers of all ages
description: Originally from the Saratov Conservatory, the group has traveled throughout Russia gathering and transcribing the native folk music traditions of countless communities. They perform traditional folk songs and dances, accompanied by authentic Russian folk instruments. The group’s repertoire includes folk songs and instrumental pieces from various parts of Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Georgia, and other areas, and also features Gypsy music, Russian popular music, and Jewish music. The members of the ensemble play more than thirty Russian folk instruments, including the bayan, chromatic and diatonic accordions, the balalaika, domra, guitar, zhaleika, clarinet, saxophone, various percussion instruments, and Russian bells. The performances provide an energetic and interactive musical experience for listeners of all ages and linguistic backgrounds.

title: Psycho Deconstruction with Alexandre Philippe
brief_description: The Lexington Film League and the Mid-Century Society of Lexington present a VERY rare cinematic experience for film lovers in Kentucky!
description:
The Lexington Film League and the Mid-Century Society of Lexington present a VERY rare cinematic experience for film lovers in Kentucky!


Documentary filmmaker Alexandre Philippe is bringing his award-winning documentary about the PSYCHO shower scene (78/52) to the Kentucky Theatre on April 8. In anticipation of that event, he will conduct a full start/stop deconstruction of the Hitchcock classic at the Farish Theater!


Mr. Philippe has become the go-to Hitchcock expert in America (he co-hosted an entire month-long retrospective on Turner Classic Movies with Ben Mankiewicz) and no one is better equipped to break down PSYCHO and give you all of the behind-the-scenes information. This is a don't-miss event and it is absolutely FREE!


If you would like to see PSYCHO in preparation for the event, we are hosting an uninterrupted screening on Wednesday, March 28 at 7 pm:


https://www.facebook.com/events/2047554785516989/

description: Weedeater picks up six years after the end of Robert Gipe’s first novel, Trampoline, and continues the story of the people of Canard County, Kentucky. In Weedeater, the reader finds Canard County living through the last hurrah of the coal industry and the most turbulent and deadly phase of the community’s battle with opioid abuse. The events it chronicles are frantic, but its voice is by turns taciturn and angry, filled with humor and stoic grace.
